It's not uncommon for children growing up in bilingual or multilingual homes to have a delay in their language development, especially if they are exposed to multiple languages at once. Research has shown that children growing up in bilingual or multilingual environments may take longer to start speaking, but they typically catch up to their peers by the time they reach school age.

It's great to hear that your child seems confident and happy, and that he is able to get his message across despite his limited vocabulary. Children are resilient and adaptable, and they can use a variety of strategies to communicate their needs and wants, such as pointing, gesturing, and using facial expressions.

However, it's still important to monitor your child's language development and provide support as needed. Here are a few things you can do to encourage your child's language development:

1. Continue to expose your child to a variety of languages. Bilingual and multilingual children have been shown to have cognitive benefits and an increased ability to learn languages in the future.
2. Speak to your child in the language you feel most comfortable speaking. This can help you to communicate more effectively with your child and build a strong bond.
3. Provide opportunities for your child to interact with other children their age. This can help your child to develop social and language skills.
4. Read books with your child in the languages you want them to learn. This can help to build vocabulary and increase their exposure to different sentence structures.

If you are concerned about your child's language development, you can consult with a speech-language pathologist who can assess your child's language skills and provide targeted strategies to support their development.
